Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: My headset pressed tight against my ear, I listened as Mr. Jensen’s voice rose, sharp and suspicious. “How do I know this isn’t a scam? I’ve been a customer for years—explain every detail!” My script blinked on the screen, but my mind was only half there. I was supposed to calmly answer, reassure, and keep him on the line. That was my job. But my phone buzzed urgently in my lap—messages from my activist group. The police had started blocking the exits at our protest downtown, and panic was spreading. I was supposed to help coordinate, send out instructions, keep everyone safe and calm. My heart pounded. I could hear the fear in the group chat, the anger in Mr. Jensen’s voice. I was expected to be present, persuasive, and professional here, but also quick-thinking, compassionate, and brave there. I gripped the phone, torn between the demands of my job and my cause, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, waiting for me to choose.
